CARDINAL . GPE was initially conceived , in DATE , as a unitary ORG although divided into provinces and municipalities with a large degree of autonomy ( Articles CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL of the LAW of DATE ) , but it is gradually moving towards a federal pattern of organisation .

This process of change , in which the main landmarks have been the constitutional reforms of DATE and CARDINAL DATE , is not yet over . Apart from a number of repercussions on central national institutions , it has been reflected in the creation of ORG ; and the position of elected representatives and electors resident in the administrative district of ORG has not remained unaffected .

In addition to this there is the system - sometimes called the " alarm bell " - provided for in LAW :

" Other than for the budgets and for Acts requiring a special majority , a reasoned motion signed by DATE of the members of CARDINAL of the language groups may be moved after the report has been tabled and before the final vote is taken in public session , stating that the provisions of a specified PERSON are likely to be seriously detrimental to relations between the ORG .

In that case the parliamentary proceedings shall be suspended and the motion referred to the ORG , which shall give a reasoned opinion on it within DATE and request the ORG concerned to vote either on this opinion or on the PERSON , possibly in amended form .
This procedure shall not be used more than once by the members of a language group in respect of any one Bill . "
These provisions are designed primarily to protect the speakers of the country ’s minority language , i.e. NORP .

On the other hand , membership of a language group does not entail any obligation to use the language concerned during parliamentary debates . Furthermore , by the terms of LAW , members of ORG and the ORG " represent the nation " as a whole , " not solely the province or subdivision of a province which has sent them to ORG " .

ORG Nothing prevents LANGUAGE - speaking candidates - whether resident in FAC or not - from standing for election in that district , or the voters - whether LANGUAGE - speaking or not - from voting for them . If they are elected , they may take the parliamentary oath in LANGUAGE or NORP as they wish , irrespective of the language they personally speak ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

Correspondingly , the LANGUAGE - speaking voters in FAC can not be represented on ORG other than by parliamentarians who have taken the oath in NORP .
Candidates are not under any obligation to state in advance which language group they will join , and they do not usually do so .
